The information for the temperature sensor.
  * **name** (**Required**, string): The name for the temperature sensor.
  
  * **id** (*Optional*, [ID](https://esphome.io/guides/configuration-types.html#config-id)): Set the ID of this sensor for use in lambdas.
  
  * All other options from [Sensor](https://esphome.io/components/sensor/index.html#config-sensor).
  
  



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/sensor/zyaura.html#configuration-variables)*

humidity.markdownDescription:
The information for the humidity sensor
  * **name** (**Required**, string): The name for the humidity sensor.
  
  * **id** (*Optional*, [ID](https://esphome.io/guides/configuration-types.html#config-id)): Set the ID of this sensor for use in lambdas.
  
  * All other options from [Sensor](https://esphome.io/components/sensor/index.html#config-sensor).
  
  



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/sensor/zyaura.html#configuration-variables)*

allOf.markdownDescription:
The ZyAura CO2 & Temperature & Humidity sensor allows you to use your [ZGm05(3)(U)](http://www.zyaura.com/products/ZGm05.asp) ([MT8057](https://masterkit.ru/shop/1266110), [MT8057S](https://medgadgets.ru/shop/kit-mt8057.html)), [ZG1683R(U)](http://www.zyaura.com/products/ZG1683R.asp) ([MT8060](https://masterkit.ru/shop/1921398)), [ZG1583RUD](http://www.zyaura.com/products/ZG1583RUD.asp) monitors with ESPHome.

*See also: [ZyAura CO2 & Temperature & Humidity Sensor](https://esphome.io/components/sensor/zyaura.html#zyaura-co2-temperature-humidity-sensor)*

sensor.markdownDescription:
ESPHome has support for many different sensors. Each of them is a platform of the `sensor` domain and each sensor has several base configuration options.

*See also: [Sensor Component](https://esphome.io/components/sensor/index.html#sensor-component)*

id.markdownDescription:
[ID](https://esphome.io/guides/configuration-types.html#config-id): Specify the ID of the stepper so that you can control it.



*See also: [A4988 Component](https://esphome.io/components/stepper/index.html#a4988-component)*

step_pin.markdownDescription:
[Pin Schema](https://esphome.io/guides/configuration-types.html#config-pin-schema): The `STEP` pin of the A4988 stepper driver.



*See also: [A4988 Component](https://esphome.io/components/stepper/index.html#a4988-component)*

dir_pin.markdownDescription:
[Pin Schema](https://esphome.io/guides/configuration-types.html#config-pin-schema): The `DIRECTION` pin of the A4988 stepper driver.



*See also: [A4988 Component](https://esphome.io/components/stepper/index.html#a4988-component)*

sleep_pin.markdownDescription:
[Pin Schema](https://esphome.io/guides/configuration-types.html#config-pin-schema): Optionally also use the `SLEEP` pin of the A4988 stepper driver. If specified, the driver will be put into sleep mode as soon as the stepper reaches the target steps.



*See also: [A4988 Component](https://esphome.io/components/stepper/index.html#a4988-component)*

id.markdownDescription:
[ID](https://esphome.io/guides/configuration-types.html#config-id): Specify the ID of the stepper so that you can control it.



*See also: [ULN2003 Component](https://esphome.io/components/stepper/index.html#uln2003-component)*

pin_a.markdownDescription:
[Pin Schema](https://esphome.io/guides/configuration-types.html#config-pin-schema): The pin **a** of the stepper control board.



*See also: [ULN2003 Component](https://esphome.io/components/stepper/index.html#uln2003-component)*

pin_b.markdownDescription:
[Pin Schema](https://esphome.io/guides/configuration-types.html#config-pin-schema): The pin **b** of the stepper control board.



*See also: [ULN2003 Component](https://esphome.io/components/stepper/index.html#uln2003-component)*

pin_c.markdownDescription:
[Pin Schema](https://esphome.io/guides/configuration-types.html#config-pin-schema): The pin **c** of the stepper control board.



*See also: [ULN2003 Component](https://esphome.io/components/stepper/index.html#uln2003-component)*

pin_d.markdownDescription:
[Pin Schema](https://esphome.io/guides/configuration-types.html#config-pin-schema): The pin **d** of the stepper control board.



*See also: [ULN2003 Component](https://esphome.io/components/stepper/index.html#uln2003-component)*

sleep_when_done.markdownDescription:
boolean: Whether to turn off all coils when the stepper has reached the target position



*See also: [ULN2003 Component](https://esphome.io/components/stepper/index.html#uln2003-component)*

step_mode.markdownDescription:
string: The step mode to operate the motor with. One of:
  * `FULL_STEP` (Default)
  
  * `HALF_STEP`
  
  * `WAVE_DRIVE`
  
  



*See also: [ULN2003 Component](https://esphome.io/components/stepper/index.html#uln2003-component)*

stepper.markdownDescription:
The `stepper` component allows you to use stepper motors with ESPHome. Currently only the A4988 stepper driver ([datasheet](https://www.pololu.com/file/0J450/a4988_DMOS_microstepping_driver_with_translator.pdf)) and ULN2003 ([datasheet](http://www.ti.com/lit/ds/symlink/uln2003a.pdf)) are supported.

*See also: [Stepper Component](https://esphome.io/components/stepper/index.html#stepper-component)*

lambda.markdownDescription:
[lambda](https://esphome.io/guides/automations.html#config-lambda): The lambda to run for instantiating the switch(es).



*See also: [Custom Switch](https://esphome.io/components/switch/custom.html#custom-switch)*

switches.markdownDescription:
list: A list of switches to initialize. The length here must equal the number of items in the `return` statement of the `lambda`.
  * All options from [Switch](https://esphome.io/components/switch/index.html#config-switch).
  
  



*See also: [Custom Switch](https://esphome.io/components/switch/custom.html#custom-switch)*

allOf.markdownDescription:
This integration can be used to create custom switches in ESPHome using the C++ (Arduino) API.

*See also: [Custom Switch](https://esphome.io/components/switch/custom.html#custom-switch)*

id.markdownDescription:
[ID](https://esphome.io/guides/configuration-types.html#config-id): Manually specify the ID used for code generation.



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/switch/gpio.html#configuration-variables)*

pin.markdownDescription:
[Pin Schema](https://esphome.io/guides/configuration-types.html#config-pin-schema): The GPIO pin to use for the switch.



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/switch/gpio.html#configuration-variables)*

restore_mode.markdownDescription:
Control how the GPIO Switch attempts to restore state on bootup. For restoring on ESP8266s, also see `esp8266_restore_from_flash` in the [esphome section](https://esphome.io/components/esphome.html).
  * `RESTORE_DEFAULT_OFF` (Default) - Attempt to restore state and default to OFF if not possible to restore.
  
  * `RESTORE_DEFAULT_ON` - Attempt to restore state and default to ON.
  
  * `ALWAYS_OFF` - Always initialize the pin as OFF on bootup.
  
  * `ALWAYS_ON` - Always initialize the pin as ON on bootup.
  
  



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/switch/gpio.html#configuration-variables)*

interlock.markdownDescription:
list: A list of other GPIO switches in an interlock group. See [Interlocking](https://esphome.io/components/switch/gpio.html#switch-gpio-interlocking).



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/switch/gpio.html#configuration-variables)*

interlock_wait_time.markdownDescription:
[Time](https://esphome.io/guides/configuration-types.html#config-time): For interlocking mode, set how long to wait after other items in an interlock group have been disabled before re-activating. Useful for motors where immediately turning on in the other direction could cause problems.



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/switch/gpio.html#configuration-variables)*

allOf.markdownDescription:
The `gpio` switch platform allows you to use any pin on your node as a switch. You can for example hook up a relay to a GPIO pin and use it through this platform.

*See also: [GPIO Switch](https://esphome.io/components/switch/gpio.html#gpio-switch)*

id.markdownDescription:
[ID](https://esphome.io/guides/configuration-types.html#config-id): Manually specify the ID used for code generation.



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/switch/output.html#configuration-variables)*

output.markdownDescription:
[ID](https://esphome.io/guides/configuration-types.html#config-id): The ID of the output component to use.



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/switch/output.html#configuration-variables)*

allOf.markdownDescription:
The `output` switch platform allows you to use any output component as a switch.

*See also: [Generic Output Switch](https://esphome.io/components/switch/output.html#generic-output-switch)*

id.markdownDescription:
[ID](https://esphome.io/guides/configuration-types.html#config-id): Manually specify the ID used for code generation.



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/switch/restart.html#configuration-variables)*

allOf.markdownDescription:
The `restart` switch platform allows you to restart your node remotely through Home Assistant.

*See also: [Restart Switch](https://esphome.io/components/switch/restart.html#restart-switch)*

id.markdownDescription:
[ID](https://esphome.io/guides/configuration-types.html#config-id): Manually specify the ID used for code generation.



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/switch/shutdown.html#configuration-variables)*

allOf.markdownDescription:
The `shutdown` switch platform allows you to shutdown your node remotely through Home Assistant. It does this by putting the node into deep sleep mode with no wakeup source selected. After enabling, the only way to startup the ESP again is by pressing the reset button or restarting the power supply.

*See also: [Shutdown Switch](https://esphome.io/components/switch/shutdown.html#shutdown-switch)*

id.markdownDescription:
[ID](https://esphome.io/guides/configuration-types.html#config-id): Manually specify the ID used for code generation.



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/switch/template.html#configuration-variables)*

lambda.markdownDescription:
[lambda](https://esphome.io/guides/automations.html#config-lambda): Lambda to be evaluated repeatedly to get the current state of the switch.



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/switch/template.html#configuration-variables)*

optimistic.markdownDescription:
boolean: Whether to operate in optimistic mode - when in this mode, any command sent to the template cover will immediately update the reported state. Defaults to `false`.



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/switch/template.html#configuration-variables)*

assumed_state.markdownDescription:
boolean: Whether the true state of the switch is not known. This will make the Home Assistant frontend show buttons for both ON and OFF actions, instead of hiding one of them when the switch is ON/OFF. Defaults to `false`.



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/switch/template.html#configuration-variables)*

turn_off_action.markdownDescription:
[Action](https://esphome.io/guides/automations.html#config-action): The action that should be performed when the remote (like Home Assistant’s frontend) requests the switch to be turned off.



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/switch/template.html#configuration-variables)*

turn_on_action.markdownDescription:
[Action](https://esphome.io/guides/automations.html#config-action): The action that should be performed when the remote (like Home Assistant’s frontend) requests the switch to be turned on.



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/switch/template.html#configuration-variables)*

restore_state.markdownDescription:
boolean: Sets whether ESPHome should attempt to restore the state on boot-up and call the turn on/off actions with the recovered values. Defaults to `no`.



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/switch/template.html#configuration-variables)*

allOf.markdownDescription:
The `template` switch platform allows you to create simple switches out of just actions and an optional value lambda. Once defined, it will automatically appear in Home Assistant as a switch and can be controlled through the frontend.

*See also: [Template Switch](https://esphome.io/components/switch/template.html#template-switch)*

id.markdownDescription:
[ID](https://esphome.io/guides/configuration-types.html#config-id): Manually specify the ID used for code generation.



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/switch/tuya.html#configuration-variables)*

switch_datapoint.markdownDescription:
int: The datapoint id number of the switch.



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/switch/tuya.html#configuration-variables)*

allOf.markdownDescription:
The `tuya` switch platform creates a sensor from a tuya serial component and requires [Tuya MCU](https://esphome.io/components/tuya.html) to be configured.

*See also: [Tuya Switch](https://esphome.io/components/switch/tuya.html#tuya-switch)*

id.markdownDescription:
[ID](https://esphome.io/guides/configuration-types.html#config-id): Manually specify the ID used for code generation.



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/switch/uart.html#configuration-variables)*

data.markdownDescription:
string or list of bytes: The data to send via UART. Either an ASCII string or a list of bytes.



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/switch/uart.html#configuration-variables)*

allOf.markdownDescription:
The `uart` switch platform allows you to send a pre-defined sequence of bytes on a [UART bus](https://esphome.io/components/uart.html) when triggered.

*See also: [UART Switch](https://esphome.io/components/switch/uart.html#uart-switch)*

switch.markdownDescription:
The `switch` domain includes all platforms that should show up like a switch and can only be turned ON or OFF.

*See also: [Switch Component](https://esphome.io/components/switch/index.html#switch-component)*

allOf.markdownDescription:
The `ble_scanner` text sensor platform lets you track reachable BLE devices. See the [BLE Tracker Configuration variables](https://esphome.io/components/esp32_ble_tracker.html#config-esp32-ble-tracker) for instructions for setting up scan parameters. The sensor platform is similar to [ESP32 Bluetooth Low Energy RSSI Sensor](https://esphome.io/components/sensor/ble_rssi.html) but in contrast to that platform, this text sensor sends out all raw BLE scan information and does not filter devices.

*See also: [ESP32 Bluetooth Low Energy Scanner](https://esphome.io/components/text_sensor/ble_scanner.html#esp32-bluetooth-low-energy-scanner)*

lambda.markdownDescription:
[lambda](https://esphome.io/guides/automations.html#config-lambda): The lambda to run for instantiating the text sensor(s).



*See also: [Custom Text Sensor](https://esphome.io/components/text_sensor/custom.html#custom-text-sensor)*

text_sensors.markdownDescription:
list: A list of text sensors to initialize. The length here must equal the number of items in the `return` statement of the `lambda`.
  * All options from [Text Sensor](https://esphome.io/components/text_sensor/index.html#config-text-sensor).
  
  



*See also: [Custom Text Sensor](https://esphome.io/components/text_sensor/custom.html#custom-text-sensor)*

allOf.markdownDescription:
This integration can be used to create custom text sensors in ESPHome using the C++ (Arduino) API.

*See also: [Custom Text Sensor](https://esphome.io/components/text_sensor/custom.html#custom-text-sensor)*

id.markdownDescription:
[ID](https://esphome.io/guides/configuration-types.html#config-id): Manually specify the ID used for code generation.



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/text_sensor/homeassistant.html#configuration-variables)*

entity_id.markdownDescription:
string: The entity ID to import from Home Assistant.



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/text_sensor/homeassistant.html#configuration-variables)*

allOf.markdownDescription:
The `homeassistant` text sensor platform allows you to create a sensors that import states from your Home Assistant instance using the [native API](https://esphome.io/components/api.html).

*See also: [Home Assistant Text Sensor](https://esphome.io/components/text_sensor/homeassistant.html#home-assistant-text-sensor)*

id.markdownDescription:
[ID](https://esphome.io/guides/configuration-types.html#config-id): Manually specify the ID used for code generation.



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/text_sensor/mqtt_subscribe.html#configuration-variables)*

topic.markdownDescription:
string: The MQTT topic to listen for numeric messages.



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/text_sensor/mqtt_subscribe.html#configuration-variables)*

qos.markdownDescription:
int: The MQTT QoS to subscribe with. Defaults to `0`.



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/text_sensor/mqtt_subscribe.html#configuration-variables)*

allOf.markdownDescription:
The `mqtt_subscribe` text sensor platform allows you to get external data into ESPHome. The sensor will subscribe to messages on the given MQTT topic and save the most recent value in its `id(mysensor).state`.

*See also: [MQTT Subscribe Text Sensor](https://esphome.io/components/text_sensor/mqtt_subscribe.html#mqtt-subscribe-text-sensor)*

id.markdownDescription:
[ID](https://esphome.io/guides/configuration-types.html#config-id): Manually specify the ID used for code generation.



*See also: [sun Text Sensor](https://esphome.io/components/sun.html#sun-text-sensor)*

type.markdownDescription:
string: The type of value to track. One of `sunrise` and `sunset`.



*See also: [sun Text Sensor](https://esphome.io/components/sun.html#sun-text-sensor)*

elevation.markdownDescription:
float: The elevation to calculate the next sunrise/sunset event for. Defaults to `0°`.



*See also: [sun Text Sensor](https://esphome.io/components/sun.html#sun-text-sensor)*

format.markdownDescription:
string: The format to format the time value with, see [Displaying Time](https://esphome.io/components/display/index.html#display-strftime) for more information. Defaults to `%X`.



*See also: [sun Text Sensor](https://esphome.io/components/sun.html#sun-text-sensor)*

id.markdownDescription:
[ID](https://esphome.io/guides/configuration-types.html#config-id): Manually specify the ID used for code generation.



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/text_sensor/template.html#configuration-variables)*

lambda.markdownDescription:
[lambda](https://esphome.io/guides/automations.html#config-lambda): Lambda to be evaluated every update interval to get the new value of the text sensor



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/text_sensor/template.html#configuration-variables)*

allOf.markdownDescription:
The `template` text sensor platform allows you to create a text sensor with templated values using [lambdas](https://esphome.io/guides/automations.html#config-lambda).

*See also: [Template Text Sensor](https://esphome.io/components/text_sensor/template.html#template-text-sensor)*

id.markdownDescription:
[ID](https://esphome.io/guides/configuration-types.html#config-id): Manually specify the ID used for code generation.



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/text_sensor/version.html#configuration-variables)*

hide_timestamp.markdownDescription:
boolean: Allows you to hide the compilation timestamp from the version string. Defaults to `False`.



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/text_sensor/version.html#configuration-variables)*

allOf.markdownDescription:
The `version` text sensor platform exposes the ESPHome version the firmware was compiled against as a text sensor.

*See also: [Version Text Sensor](https://esphome.io/components/text_sensor/version.html#version-text-sensor)*

ip_address.markdownDescription:
Expose the IP Address of the ESP as a text sensor. All options from [Text Sensor](https://esphome.io/components/text_sensor/index.html#config-text-sensor).



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/text_sensor/wifi_info.html#configuration-variables)*

ssid.markdownDescription:
Expose the SSID of the currently connected WiFi network as a text sensor. All options from [Text Sensor](https://esphome.io/components/text_sensor/index.html#config-text-sensor).



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/text_sensor/wifi_info.html#configuration-variables)*

bssid.markdownDescription:
Expose the BSSID of the currently connected WiFi network as a text sensor. All options from [Text Sensor](https://esphome.io/components/text_sensor/index.html#config-text-sensor).



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/text_sensor/wifi_info.html#configuration-variables)*

mac_address.markdownDescription:
Expose the Mac Address of the WiFi card. All options from [Text Sensor](https://esphome.io/components/text_sensor/index.html#config-text-sensor).



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/text_sensor/wifi_info.html#configuration-variables)*

allOf.markdownDescription:
The `wifi_info` text sensor platform exposes different WiFi information via text sensors.

*See also: [WiFi Info Text Sensor](https://esphome.io/components/text_sensor/wifi_info.html#wifi-info-text-sensor)*

text_sensor.markdownDescription:
Text sensors are a lot like normal [sensors](https://esphome.io/components/sensor/index.html). But where the “normal” sensors only represent sensors that output **numbers**, this component can represent any *text*.

*See also: [Text Sensor Component](https://esphome.io/components/text_sensor/index.html#text-sensor-component)*

allOf.markdownDescription:
You first need to set up the [I2C](https://esphome.io/components/i2c.html) component.

*See also: [DS1307 Time Source](https://esphome.io/components/time.html#ds1307-time-source)*

You first need to set up the [GPS](https://esphome.io/components/gps.html) component.

*See also: [GPS Time Source](https://esphome.io/components/time.html#gps-time-source)*

The preferred way to get time in ESPHome is using Home Assistant. With the `homeassistant` time platform, the [native API](https://esphome.io/components/api.html) connection to Home Assistant will be used to periodically synchronize the current time.

*See also: [Home Assistant Time Source](https://esphome.io/components/time.html#home-assistant-time-source)*

servers.markdownDescription:
list of strings: Choose up to 3 NTP servers that are used for the clock source. Defaults to `0.pool.ntp.org`, `1.pool.ntp.org` and `2.pool.ntp.org`



*See also: [SNTP Time Source](https://esphome.io/components/time.html#sntp-time-source)*

allOf.markdownDescription:
Configuration variables:

*See also: [SNTP Time Source](https://esphome.io/components/time.html#sntp-time-source)*

time.markdownDescription:
The `time` component allows you to set up real time clock time sources for ESPHome. You can then get the current time in [lambdas](https://esphome.io/guides/automations.html#config-lambda).

*See also: [Time](https://esphome.io/components/time.html#time)*

animation.markdownDescription:
Allows to use animated images on displays. Animation inherits all options from the image component. It adds an additional lambda method: `next_frame()` to change the shown picture of a gif.

*See also: [Animation](https://esphome.io/components/display/index.html#animation)*

id.markdownDescription:
[ID](https://esphome.io/guides/configuration-types.html#config-id): Manually specify the ID used for code generation.



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/api.html#configuration-variables)*

port.markdownDescription:
integer: The port to run the API Server on. Defaults to `6053`.



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/api.html#configuration-variables)*

password.markdownDescription:
string: The password to protect the API Server with. Defaults to no password.



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/api.html#configuration-variables)*

reboot_timeout.markdownDescription:
[time](https://esphome.io/guides/configuration-types.html#config-time): The amount of time to wait before rebooting when no client connects to the API. This is needed because sometimes the low level ESP functions report that the ESP is connected to the network, when in fact it is not - only a full reboot fixes it. Can be disabled by setting this to `0s`. Defaults to `15min`.



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/api.html#configuration-variables)*

services.markdownDescription:
list: A list of user-defined services. See [User-defined Services](https://esphome.io/components/api.html#api-services).



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/api.html#configuration-variables)*

api.markdownDescription:
The ESPHome native API is used to communicate with clients directly, with a highly-optimized network protocol. Currently, only the ESPHome tool and Home Assistant use this native API.

*See also: [Native API Component](https://esphome.io/components/api.html#native-api-component)*

irq_pin.markdownDescription:
[Pin](https://esphome.io/guides/configuration-types.html#config-pin): The IRQ pin, which indicates if a lightning strike has been detected.



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/sensor/as3935.html#id1)*

indoor.markdownDescription:
boolean: Indicates if the sensor is used indoor. Defaults to `true`.



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/sensor/as3935.html#id1)*

noise_level.markdownDescription:
integer: Noise floor level is compared to known reference voltage. If this level is exceeded the chip will issue an interrupt to the IRQ pin, broadcasting that it can not operate properly due to noise (INT_NH). Defaults to `2`.



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/sensor/as3935.html#id1)*

watchdog_threshold.markdownDescription:
integer: Determines the threshold for events that trigger the IRQ pin. Defaults to `2`.



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/sensor/as3935.html#id1)*

spike_rejection.markdownDescription:
integer: Helps to differentiate between real events and actual lightning. Increasing this value increases robustness at the cost of sensitivity to distant events. Defaults to `2`.



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/sensor/as3935.html#id1)*

lightning_threshold.markdownDescription:
integer: The number of lightnings that must appear in a 15-minute time window before a lightning storm is detected. 15 minutes is the window of time before the number of detected lightning events is reset. The number of lightning strikes can be set to 1,5,9, or 16. Defaults to `1`.



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/sensor/as3935.html#id1)*

mask_disturber.markdownDescription:
boolean: This setting will return whether or not disturbers trigger the IRQ Pin. Defaults to `false`.



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/sensor/as3935.html#id1)*

div_ratio.markdownDescription:
integer: The antenna is designed to resonate at 500kHz and so can be tuned with the following setting. The accuracy of the antenna must be within 3.5 percent of that value for proper signal validation and distance estimation. Defaults to `0`.



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/sensor/as3935.html#id1)*

capacitance.markdownDescription:
integer: This setting will add capacitance to the series RLC antenna on the product to help tune its resonance. The datasheet specifies being within 3.5 percent of 500kHz to get optimal lightning detection and distance sensing. It’s possible to add up to 120pF in steps of 8pF to the antenna. Defaults to `0`.



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/sensor/as3935.html#id1)*

as3935_i2c.markdownDescription:
The `as3935_i2c` sensor platform allows you to use your AS3935 sensor ([AliExpress](https://de.aliexpress.com/af/as3935.html?SearchText=as3935), [AMS_AS3935](https://ams.com/as3935)) in order to get notified when a thunderstorm is getting close.

*See also: [Over I²C](https://esphome.io/components/sensor/as3935.html#over-i2c)*

irq_pin.markdownDescription:
[Pin](https://esphome.io/guides/configuration-types.html#config-pin): The IRQ pin, which indicates if a lightning strike has been detected.



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/sensor/as3935.html#configuration-variables)*

indoor.markdownDescription:
boolean: Indicates if the sensor is used indoor. Defaults to `true`.



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/sensor/as3935.html#configuration-variables)*

noise_level.markdownDescription:
integer: Noise floor level is compared to known reference voltage. If this level is exceeded the chip will issue an interrupt to the IRQ pin, broadcasting that it can not operate properly due to noise (INT_NH). Defaults to `2`.



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/sensor/as3935.html#configuration-variables)*

watchdog_threshold.markdownDescription:
integer: Determines the threshold for events that trigger the IRQ pin. Defaults to `2`.



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/sensor/as3935.html#configuration-variables)*

spike_rejection.markdownDescription:
integer: Helps to differentiate between real events and actual lightning. Increasing this value increases robustness at the cost of sensitivity to distant events. Defaults to `2`.



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/sensor/as3935.html#configuration-variables)*

lightning_threshold.markdownDescription:
integer: The number of lightnings that must appear in a 15-minute time window before a lightning storm is detected. 15 minutes is the window of time before the number of detected lightning events is reset. The number of lightning strikes can be set to 1,5,9, or 16. Defaults to `1`.



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/sensor/as3935.html#configuration-variables)*

mask_disturber.markdownDescription:
boolean: This setting will return whether or not disturbers trigger the IRQ Pin. Defaults to `false`.



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/sensor/as3935.html#configuration-variables)*

div_ratio.markdownDescription:
integer: The antenna is designed to resonate at 500kHz and so can be tuned with the following setting. The accuracy of the antenna must be within 3.5 percent of that value for proper signal validation and distance estimation. Defaults to `0`.



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/sensor/as3935.html#configuration-variables)*

capacitance.markdownDescription:
integer: This setting will add capacitance to the series RLC antenna on the product to help tune its resonance. The datasheet specifies being within 3.5 percent of 500kHz to get optimal lightning detection and distance sensing. It’s possible to add up to 120pF in steps of 8pF to the antenna. Defaults to `0`.



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/sensor/as3935.html#configuration-variables)*

as3935_spi.markdownDescription:
The `as3935_spi` sensor platform allows you to use your AS3935 sensor ([AliExpress](https://de.aliexpress.com/af/as3935.html?SearchText=as3935), [AMS_AS3935](https://ams.com/as3935)) in order to get notified when a thunderstorm is getting close.

*See also: [Over SPI](https://esphome.io/components/sensor/as3935.html#over-spi)*

captive_portal.markdownDescription:
The captive portal component in ESPHome is a fallback mechanism for when connecting to the configured [WiFi](https://esphome.io/components/wifi.html) fails.

*See also: [Captive Portal](https://esphome.io/components/captive_portal.html#captive-portal)*

color.markdownDescription:
When using RGB-capable displays in ESPHome you may wish to use custom colors. A `color` component exists for just this purpose:

*See also: [Color](https://esphome.io/components/display/index.html#color)*

custom_component.markdownDescription:
This integration can be used to create generic custom components in ESPHome using the C++ (Arduino) API. This integration should be used in cases where none of ESPHome’s abstraction layers (for example the “sensor”, “binary sensor”, “switch”, etc concepts) work well for your integration.

*See also: [Generic Custom Component](https://esphome.io/custom/custom_component.html#generic-custom-component)*

debug.markdownDescription:
The `debug` component can be used to debug problems with ESPHome. At startup, it prints a bunch of useful information like reset reason, free heap size, ESPHome version and so on.

*See also: [Debug Component](https://esphome.io/components/debug.html#debug-component)*

id.markdownDescription:
[ID](https://esphome.io/guides/configuration-types.html#config-id): Manually specify the ID used for code generation.



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/deep_sleep.html#configuration-variables)*

run_duration.markdownDescription:
[Time](https://esphome.io/guides/configuration-types.html#config-time): The time duration the node should be active, i.e. run code.



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/deep_sleep.html#configuration-variables)*

sleep_duration.markdownDescription:
[Time](https://esphome.io/guides/configuration-types.html#config-time): The time duration to stay in deep sleep mode.



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/deep_sleep.html#configuration-variables)*

wakeup_pin.markdownDescription:
[Pin Schema](https://esphome.io/guides/configuration-types.html#config-pin-schema): Only on ESP32. A pin to wake up to once in deep sleep mode. Use the inverted property to wake up to LOW signals.



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/deep_sleep.html#configuration-variables)*

wakeup_pin_mode.markdownDescription:
Only on ESP32. Specify how to handle waking up from a `wakeup_pin` if the wakeup pin is already in the state with which it would wake up when attempting to enter deep sleep. See [ESP32 Wakeup Pin Mode](https://esphome.io/components/deep_sleep.html#deep-sleep-esp32-wakeup-pin-mode). Defaults to `IGNORE`



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/deep_sleep.html#configuration-variables)*

esp32_ext1_wakeup.markdownDescription:
Use the EXT1 wakeup source of the ESP32 to wake from deep sleep to wake up on multiple pins. This cannot be used together with wakeup pin.
  * **pins** (**Required**, list of pin numbers): The pins to wake up on.
  
  * **mode** (*Optional*): The mode to use for the wakeup source. Must be one of `ALL_LOW` (wake up when all pins go LOW) or `ANY_HIGH` (wake up when any pin goes HIGH).
  
  



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/deep_sleep.html#configuration-variables)*

deep_sleep.markdownDescription:
The `deep_sleep` component can be used to automatically enter a deep sleep mode on the ESP8266/ESP32 after a certain amount of time. This is especially useful with nodes that operate on batteries and therefore need to conserve as much energy as possible.

*See also: [Deep Sleep Component](https://esphome.io/components/deep_sleep.html#deep-sleep-component)*

dfplayer.markdownDescription:
The `dfplayer` ([datasheet](https://wiki.dfrobot.com/DFPlayer_Mini_SKU_DFR0299)), component allows you to play sound and music stored in an SD card or USB flash drive.

*See also: [DF-Player mini](https://esphome.io/components/dfplayer.html#df-player-mini)*

method.markdownDescription:
Listening method, one of `multicast` or `unicast`. Defaults to `multicast`.



*See also: [E1.31 Component](https://esphome.io/components/light/index.html#e1-31-component)*

id.markdownDescription:
[ID](https://esphome.io/guides/configuration-types.html#config-id): Manually specify the ID for code generation.



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/esp32_ble_beacon.html#configuration-variables)*

type.markdownDescription:
The type of beacon to create, currently only supports `iBeacon`.



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/esp32_ble_beacon.html#configuration-variables)*

uuid.markdownDescription:
The [universally unique identifier](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Universally_unique_identifier) to identify the beacon.



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/esp32_ble_beacon.html#configuration-variables)*

major.markdownDescription:
integer: The iBeacon major identifier of this beacon. Usually used to group beacons, for example for grouping all beacons in the same building, but has no effect if the BLE receiver doesn’t use it. Defaults to `10167`.



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/esp32_ble_beacon.html#configuration-variables)*

minor.markdownDescription:
integer: The iBeacon minor identifier of this beacon. Usually used to identify beacons within an iBeacon group. Defaults to `61958`.



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/esp32_ble_beacon.html#configuration-variables)*

esp32_ble_beacon.markdownDescription:
The `esp32_ble_beacon` component creates a Bluetooth Low Energy Beacon with your ESP32 device. Beacons are BLE devices that repeatedly just send out a pre-defined packet of data. This packet can then be received by devices like smartphones and can then be used to track a phone’s location.

*See also: [ESP32 Bluetooth Low Energy Beacon](https://esphome.io/components/esp32_ble_beacon.html#esp32-bluetooth-low-energy-beacon)*

id.markdownDescription:
[ID](https://esphome.io/guides/configuration-types.html#config-id): Manually specify the ID for this ESP32 BLE Hub.



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/esp32_ble_tracker.html#configuration-variables)*

scan_parameters.markdownDescription:
Advanced parameters for configuring the scan behavior of the ESP32. See also [this guide by Texas Instruments](http://dev.ti.com/tirex/content/simplelink_academy_cc2640r2sdk_1_12_01_16/modules/ble_scan_adv_basic/ble_scan_adv_basic.html#scanning) for reference.
  * **interval** (*Optional*, [Time](https://esphome.io/guides/configuration-types.html#config-time)): The interval between each consecutive scan window. This is the time the ESP spends on each of the 3 BLE advertising channels. Defaults to `320ms`.
  
  * **window** (*Optional*, [Time](https://esphome.io/guides/configuration-types.html#config-time)): The time the ESP is actively listening for packets on a channel during each scan interval. If this is close to the `interval` value, the ESP will spend more time listening to packets (but also consume more power).
  
  * **duration** (*Optional*, [Time](https://esphome.io/guides/configuration-types.html#config-time)): The duration of each complete scan. This has no real impact on the device but can be used to debug the BLE stack. Defaults to `5min`.
  
  * **active** (*Optional*, boolean): Whether to actively send scan requests to request more data after having received an advertising packet. With some devices this is necessary to receive all data, but also drains those devices’ power a (tiny) bit more. Defaults to `true`.
  
  



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/esp32_ble_tracker.html#configuration-variables)*

on_ble_advertise.markdownDescription:
[Automation](https://esphome.io/guides/automations.html#automation): An automation to perform when a Bluetooth advertising is received. See [on_ble_advertise](https://esphome.io/components/esp32_ble_tracker.html#esp32-ble-tracker-on-ble-advertise).



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/esp32_ble_tracker.html#configuration-variables)*

on_ble_service_data_advertise.markdownDescription:
[Automation](https://esphome.io/guides/automations.html#automation): An automation to perform when a Bluetooth advertising with service data is received. See [on_ble_service_data_advertise](https://esphome.io/components/esp32_ble_tracker.html#esp32-ble-tracker-on-ble-service-data-advertise).



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/esp32_ble_tracker.html#configuration-variables)*

on_ble_manufacturer_data_advertise.markdownDescription:
[Automation](https://esphome.io/guides/automations.html#automation): An automation to perform when a Bluetooth advertising with manufcaturer data is received. See [on_ble_manufacturer_data_advertise](https://esphome.io/components/esp32_ble_tracker.html#esp32-ble-tracker-on-ble-manufacturer-data-advertise).



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/esp32_ble_tracker.html#configuration-variables)*

esp32_ble_tracker.markdownDescription:
The `esp32_ble_tracker` component creates a global hub so that you can track bluetooth low energy devices using your ESP32 node.

*See also: [ESP32 Bluetooth Low Energy Tracker Hub](https://esphome.io/components/esp32_ble_tracker.html#esp32-bluetooth-low-energy-tracker-hub)*

name.markdownDescription:
string: The name of the camera.



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/esp32_camera.html#configuration-variables)*

data_pins.markdownDescription:
list of pins: The data lanes of the camera, this must be a list of 8 GPIO pins.



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/esp32_camera.html#configuration-variables)*

vsync_pin.markdownDescription:
pin: The pin the VSYNC line of the camera is connected to.



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/esp32_camera.html#configuration-variables)*

href_pin.markdownDescription:
pin: The pin the HREF line of the camera is connected to.



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/esp32_camera.html#configuration-variables)*

pixel_clock_pin.markdownDescription:
pin: The pin the pixel clock line of the camera is connected to.



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/esp32_camera.html#configuration-variables)*

external_clock.markdownDescription:
The configuration of the external clock to drive the camera.
  * **pin** (**Required**, pin): The pin the external clock line is connected to.
  
  * **frequency** (*Optional*, float): The frequency of the external clock, must be either 20MHz or 10MHz. Defaults to `20MHz`.
  
  



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/esp32_camera.html#configuration-variables)*

i2c_pins.markdownDescription:
The I²C control pins of the camera.
  * **sda** (**Required**, pin): The SDA pin of the I²C interface. Also called `SIOD`.
  
  * **scl** (**Required**, pin): The SCL pin of the I²C interface. Also called `SIOC`.
  
  



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/esp32_camera.html#configuration-variables)*

reset_pin.markdownDescription:
pin: The ESP pin the reset pin of the camera is connected to. If set, this will reset the camera before the ESP boots.



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/esp32_camera.html#configuration-variables)*

power_down_pin.markdownDescription:
pin: The ESP pin to power down the camera. If set, this will power down the camera while it is inactive.



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/esp32_camera.html#configuration-variables)*

max_framerate.markdownDescription:
float: The maximum framerate the camera will generate images at. Up to 60Hz is possible (with reduced frame sizes), but beware of overheating. Defaults to `10 fps`.



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/esp32_camera.html#configuration-variables)*

idle_framerate.markdownDescription:
float: The framerate to capture images at when no client is requesting a full stream. Defaults to `0.1 fps`.



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/esp32_camera.html#configuration-variables)*

resolution.markdownDescription:
enum: The resolution the camera will capture images at. Higher resolutions require more memory, if there’s not enough memory you will see an error during startup.
  * `160x120` (QQVGA)
  
  * `128x160` (QQVGA2)
  
  * `176x144` (QCIF)
  
  * `240x176` (HQVGA)
  
  * `320x240` (QVGA)
  
  * `400x296` (CIF)
  
  * `640x480` (VGA, default)
  
  * `800x600` (SVGA)
  
  * `1024x768` (XGA)
  
  * `1280x1024` (SXGA)
  
  * `1600x1200` (UXGA)
  
  



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/esp32_camera.html#configuration-variables)*

jpeg_quality.markdownDescription:
int: The JPEG quality that the camera should encode images with. From 10 (best) to 63 (worst). Defaults to `10`.



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/esp32_camera.html#configuration-variables)*

contrast.markdownDescription:
int: The contrast to apply to the picture, from -2 to 2. Defaults to `0`.



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/esp32_camera.html#configuration-variables)*

brightness.markdownDescription:
int: The brightness to apply to the picture, from -2 to 2. Defaults to `0`.



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/esp32_camera.html#configuration-variables)*

saturation.markdownDescription:
int: The saturation to apply to the picture, from -2 to 2. Defaults to `0`.



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/esp32_camera.html#configuration-variables)*

vertical_flip.markdownDescription:
bool: Whether to flip the image vertically. Defaults to `true`.



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/esp32_camera.html#configuration-variables)*

horizontal_mirror.markdownDescription:
bool: Whether to mirror the image horizontally. Defaults to `true`.



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/esp32_camera.html#configuration-variables)*

test_pattern.markdownDescription:
boolean: When enabled, the camera will show a test pattern that can be used to debug connection issues.



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/esp32_camera.html#configuration-variables)*

esp32_camera.markdownDescription:
The `esp32_camera` component allows you to use ESP32-based camera boards in ESPHome that directly integrate into Home Assistant through the native API.

*See also: [ESP32 Camera Component](https://esphome.io/components/esp32_camera.html#esp32-camera-component)*

id.markdownDescription:
[ID](https://esphome.io/guides/configuration-types.html#config-id): Manually specify the ID for code generation.



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/binary_sensor/esp32_touch.html#configuration-variables)*

setup_mode.markdownDescription:
boolean: Whether debug messages with the touch pad value should be displayed in the logs. Useful for finding out suitable thresholds for the binary sensors, but spam the logs. See [setting up touch pads](https://esphome.io/components/binary_sensor/esp32_touch.html#esp32-touch-binary-sensor) for more information. Defaults to false.



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/binary_sensor/esp32_touch.html#configuration-variables)*

iir_filter.markdownDescription:
[Time](https://esphome.io/guides/configuration-types.html#config-time): Optionally set up an [Infinite Impulse Response](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Infinite_impulse_response) filter should be applied to all touch pads. This can increase the accuracy of the touch pads a lot, but higher values decrease the response time. A good value to start with is `10ms`. Default is no IIR filter.



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/binary_sensor/esp32_touch.html#configuration-variables)*

sleep_duration.markdownDescription:
[Time](https://esphome.io/guides/configuration-types.html#config-time): Set a time period denoting the amount of time the touch peripheral should sleep between measurements. This can decrease power usage but make the sensor slower. Default is about 27 milliseconds.



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/binary_sensor/esp32_touch.html#configuration-variables)*

measurement_duration.markdownDescription:
[Time](https://esphome.io/guides/configuration-types.html#config-time): Set the conversion time for all touch pads. A longer conversion time means that more charge/discharge cycles of the touch pad can be performed, therefore increasing accuracy. Default is about 8ms, the maximum amount.



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/binary_sensor/esp32_touch.html#configuration-variables)*

low_voltage_reference.markdownDescription:
The low voltage reference to use for the charge cycles. See the [esp-idf docs](https://docs.espressif.com/projects/esp-idf/en/latest/api-reference/peripherals/touch_pad.html#optimization-of-measurements) for a nice explanation of this. One of `0.5V`, `0.6V`, `0.7V`, `0.8V`. Default is `0.5V`.



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/binary_sensor/esp32_touch.html#configuration-variables)*

high_voltage_reference.markdownDescription:
The high voltage reference to use for the charge cycles. See the [esp-idf docs](https://docs.espressif.com/projects/esp-idf/en/latest/api-reference/peripherals/touch_pad.html#optimization-of-measurements) for a nice explanation of this. One of `2.4V`, `2.5V`, `2.6V`, `2.7V`. Default is `2.7V`.



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/binary_sensor/esp32_touch.html#configuration-variables)*

voltage_attenuation.markdownDescription:
The voltage attenuation to use for the charge cycles. See the [esp-idf docs](https://docs.espressif.com/projects/esp-idf/en/latest/api-reference/peripherals/touch_pad.html#optimization-of-measurements) for a nice explanation of this. One of `1.5V`, `1V`, `0.5V`, `0V`. Default is `0V`.



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/binary_sensor/esp32_touch.html#configuration-variables)*

id.markdownDescription:
[ID](https://esphome.io/guides/configuration-types.html#config-id): Manually specify the ID used for code generation.



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/ethernet.html#configuration-variables)*

type.markdownDescription:
string: The type of LAN chipset. Must be one of `LAN8720` or `TLK110` (see datasheet for more details).



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/ethernet.html#configuration-variables)*

mdc_pin.markdownDescription:
[Pin](https://esphome.io/guides/configuration-types.html#config-pin): The MDC pin of the board. Usually this is `GPIO23`.



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/ethernet.html#configuration-variables)*

mdio_pin.markdownDescription:
[Pin](https://esphome.io/guides/configuration-types.html#config-pin): The MDIO pin of the board. Usually this is `GPIO18`.



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/ethernet.html#configuration-variables)*

clk_mode.markdownDescription:
string: The clock mode of the data lines, this must be one of these values: (see datasheet of your board for more details)
  * `GPIO0_IN` (Default) - External clock
  
  * `GPIO0_OUT` - Internal clock
  
  * `GPIO16_OUT` - Internal clock
  
  * `GPIO17_OUT` - Internal clock
  
  



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/ethernet.html#configuration-variables)*

phy_addr.markdownDescription:
int: The PHY addr type of the ethernet controller. Defaults to 0.



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/ethernet.html#configuration-variables)*

power_pin.markdownDescription:
[Pin Schema](https://esphome.io/guides/configuration-types.html#config-pin-schema): The pin with which to control the power of the board. Leave unspecified for no power pin (default)



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/ethernet.html#configuration-variables)*

manual_ip.markdownDescription:
Manually configure the static IP of the node.
  * **static_ip** (**Required**, IPv4 address): The static IP of your node.
  
  * **gateway** (**Required**, IPv4 address): The gateway of the local network.
  
  * **subnet** (**Required**, IPv4 address): The subnet of the local network.
  
  * **dns1** (*Optional*, IPv4 address): The main DNS server to use.
  
  * **dns2** (*Optional*, IPv4 address): The backup DNS server to use.
  
  



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/ethernet.html#configuration-variables)*

domain.markdownDescription:
string: Set the domain of the node hostname used for uploading. For example, if it’s set to `.local`, all uploads will be sent to `<HOSTNAME>.local`. Defaults to `.local`.



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/ethernet.html#configuration-variables)*

ethernet.markdownDescription:
This core ESPHome component sets up ethernet connections for ESP32s. Ethernet for ESP8266 is not supported.

*See also: [Ethernet Component](https://esphome.io/components/ethernet.html#ethernet-component)*

on_exposure_notification.markdownDescription:
[Automation](https://esphome.io/guides/automations.html#automation): An automation to run when an exposure notification bluetooth message is received.A variable `x` of type [exposure_notifications::ExposureNotification](https://esphome.io/api/structesphome_1_1exposure__notifications_1_1_exposure_notification.html) is passed to the automation.



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/exposure_notifications.html#configuration-variables)*

exposure_notifications.markdownDescription:
The `exposure_notifications` component uses the [ESP32 Bluetooth Low Energy Tracker Hub](https://esphome.io/components/esp32_ble_tracker.html) to discover nearby COVID-19 exposure notification bluetooth messages sent by phones running the [Google/Apple Exposure Notification service](https://www.google.com/covid19/exposurenotifications/).

*See also: [Exposure Notification Listener](https://esphome.io/components/exposure_notifications.html#exposure-notification-listener)*

font.markdownDescription:
The rendering engine also has a powerful font drawer which integrates seamlessly into ESPHome. Whereas in most Arduino display projects you have to use one of a few pre-defined fonts in very specific sizes, with ESPHome you have the option to use **any** TrueType (`.ttf`) font file at **any** size! Granted the reason for it is actually not having to worry about the licensing of font files :)

*See also: [Drawing Static Text](https://esphome.io/components/display/index.html#drawing-static-text)*

globals.markdownDescription:
In some cases you might require to share a global variable across multiple lambdas. For example, global variables can be used to store the state of a garage door.

*See also: [Global Variables](https://esphome.io/guides/automations.html#global-variables)*

gps.markdownDescription:
The `gps` component allows you to connect GPS modules to your ESPHome project. Any GPS module that uses the standardized NMEA communication protocol will work.

*See also: [GPS Component](https://esphome.io/components/gps.html#gps-component)*

id.markdownDescription:
[ID](https://esphome.io/guides/configuration-types.html#config-id): Manually specify the ID used for code generation.



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/http_request.html#configuration-variables)*

useragent.markdownDescription:
string: User-Agent header for requests. Defaults to `ESPHome`.



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/http_request.html#configuration-variables)*

timeout.markdownDescription:
[time](https://esphome.io/guides/configuration-types.html#config-time): Timeout for request. Defaults to `5s`.



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/http_request.html#configuration-variables)*

http_request.markdownDescription:
The `http_request` component lets you make HTTP/HTTPS requests.

*See also: [HTTP Request](https://esphome.io/components/http_request.html#http-request)*

i2c.markdownDescription:
This component sets up the I²C bus for your ESP32 or ESP8266. In order for these components to work correctly, you need to define the I²C bus in your configuration. Please note the ESP will enable its internal 10kΩ pullup resistors for these pins, so you usually don’t need to put on external ones. You can use multiple devices on one I²C bus as each device is given a unique address for communicating between between it and the ESP. You can do this by hopping wires from the two lines (SDA and SCL) from each device board to the next device board or by connecting the wires from each device back to the two I²C pins on the ESP.

*See also: [I²C Bus](https://esphome.io/components/i2c.html#i2c-bus)*

image.markdownDescription:
Use this component to store graphical images on the device, you can then draw the images on compatible displays.

*See also: [Images](https://esphome.io/components/display/index.html#images)*

id.markdownDescription:
[ID](https://esphome.io/guides/configuration-types.html#config-id): Manually specify the ID used for code generation.



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/logger.html#configuration-variables)*

baud_rate.markdownDescription:
int: The baud rate to use for the serial UART port. Defaults to `115200`. Set to `0` to disable logging via UART.



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/logger.html#configuration-variables)*

tx_buffer_size.markdownDescription:
int: The size of the buffer used for log messages. Decrease this if you’re having memory problems. Defaults to `512`.



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/logger.html#configuration-variables)*

hardware_uart.markdownDescription:
string: The Hardware UART to use for logging. Defaults to `UART0`.



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/logger.html#configuration-variables)*

level.markdownDescription:
string: The global log level. Any log message with a lower severity will not be shown. Defaults to `DEBUG`.



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/logger.html#configuration-variables)*

logs.markdownDescription:
mapping: Manually set the log level for a specific component or tag. See [Manual Log Levels for more information](https://esphome.io/components/logger.html#logger-manual-tag-specific-levels).



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/logger.html#configuration-variables)*

on_message.markdownDescription:
[Automation](https://esphome.io/guides/automations.html#automation): An action to be performed when a message is to be looged. The vairables `int level`, `const char* tag` and `const char* message` are available for lambda processing.



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/logger.html#configuration-variables)*

esp8266_store_log_strings_in_flash.markdownDescription:
boolean: If set to false, disables storing log strings in the flash section of the device (uses more memory). Defaults to true.



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/logger.html#configuration-variables)*

logger.markdownDescription:
The logger component automatically logs all log messages through the serial port and through MQTT topics. By default, all logs with a severity higher than `DEBUG` will be shown. Decreasing the log level can help with the performance of the application and memory size.

*See also: [Logger Component](https://esphome.io/components/logger.html#logger-component)*

id.markdownDescription:
[ID](https://esphome.io/guides/configuration-types.html#config-id): Manually specify the ID used for code generation.



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/mqtt.html#configuration-variables)*

broker.markdownDescription:
string: The host of your MQTT broker.



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/mqtt.html#configuration-variables)*

port.markdownDescription:
int: The port to connect to. Defaults to 1883.



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/mqtt.html#configuration-variables)*

username.markdownDescription:
string: The username to use for authentication. Empty (the default) means no authentication.



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/mqtt.html#configuration-variables)*

password.markdownDescription:
string: The password to use for authentication. Empty (the default) means no authentication.



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/mqtt.html#configuration-variables)*

client_id.markdownDescription:
string: The client id to use for opening connections. See [Defaults](https://esphome.io/components/mqtt.html#mqtt-defaults) for more information.



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/mqtt.html#configuration-variables)*

discovery.markdownDescription:
boolean: If Home Assistant automatic discovery should be enabled. Defaults to `True`.



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/mqtt.html#configuration-variables)*

discovery_retain.markdownDescription:
boolean: Whether to retain MQTT discovery messages so that entities are added automatically on Home Assistant restart. Defaults to `True`.



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/mqtt.html#configuration-variables)*

discovery_prefix.markdownDescription:
string: The prefix to use for Home Assistant’s MQTT discovery. Should not contain trailing slash. Defaults to `homeassistant`.



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/mqtt.html#configuration-variables)*

birth_message.markdownDescription:
[MQTTMessage](https://esphome.io/components/mqtt.html#mqtt-message): The message to send when a connection to the broker is established. See [Last Will And Birth Messages](https://esphome.io/components/mqtt.html#mqtt-last-will-birth) for more information.



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/mqtt.html#configuration-variables)*

will_message.markdownDescription:
[MQTTMessage](https://esphome.io/components/mqtt.html#mqtt-message): The message to send when the MQTT connection is dropped. See [Last Will And Birth Messages](https://esphome.io/components/mqtt.html#mqtt-last-will-birth) for more information.



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/mqtt.html#configuration-variables)*

shutdown_message.markdownDescription:
[MQTTMessage](https://esphome.io/components/mqtt.html#mqtt-message): The message to send when the node shuts down and the connection is closed cleanly. See [Last Will And Birth Messages](https://esphome.io/components/mqtt.html#mqtt-last-will-birth) for more information.



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/mqtt.html#configuration-variables)*

topic_prefix.markdownDescription:
string: The prefix used for all MQTT messages. Should not contain trailing slash. Defaults to `<APP_NAME>`.



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/mqtt.html#configuration-variables)*

log_topic.markdownDescription:
[MQTTMessage](https://esphome.io/components/mqtt.html#mqtt-message): The topic to send MQTT log messages to.



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/mqtt.html#configuration-variables)*

ssl_fingerprints.markdownDescription:
list: Only on ESP8266. A list of SHA1 hashes used for verifying SSL connections. See [SSL Fingerprints](https://esphome.io/components/mqtt.html#mqtt-ssl-fingerprints) for more information.



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/mqtt.html#configuration-variables)*

keepalive.markdownDescription:
[Time](https://esphome.io/guides/configuration-types.html#config-time): The time to keep the MQTT socket alive, decreasing this can help with overall stability due to more WiFi traffic with more pings. Defaults to 15 seconds.



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/mqtt.html#configuration-variables)*

reboot_timeout.markdownDescription:
[time](https://esphome.io/guides/configuration-types.html#config-time): The amount of time to wait before rebooting when no MQTT connection exists. Can be disabled by setting this to `0s`. Defaults to `15min`.



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/mqtt.html#configuration-variables)*

on_message.markdownDescription:
[Automation](https://esphome.io/guides/automations.html#automation): An action to be performed when a message on a specific MQTT topic is received. See [on_message Trigger](https://esphome.io/components/mqtt.html#mqtt-on-message).



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/mqtt.html#configuration-variables)*

on_json_message.markdownDescription:
[Automation](https://esphome.io/guides/automations.html#automation): An action to be performed when a JSON message on a specific MQTT topic is received. See [on_json_message Trigger](https://esphome.io/components/mqtt.html#mqtt-on-json-message).



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/mqtt.html#configuration-variables)*

mqtt.markdownDescription:
The MQTT Client Component sets up the MQTT connection to your broker and is currently required for ESPHome to work. In most cases, you will just be able to copy over the [MQTT section](https://www.home-assistant.io/components/mqtt/) of your Home Assistant configuration.

*See also: [MQTT Client Component](https://esphome.io/components/mqtt.html#mqtt-client-component)*

ota.markdownDescription:
With the OTA (Over The Air) update component you can upload your firmware binaries to your node without having to use an USB cable for uploads. ESPHome natively supports this through its `run` and `upload` helper scripts.

*See also: [OTA Update Component](https://esphome.io/components/ota.html#ota-update-component)*

pcf8574.markdownDescription:
The PCF8574 component allows you to use PCF8574 or PCF8575 I/O expanders ([datasheet](http://www.ti.com/lit/ds/symlink/pcf8574.pdf), [SparkFun](https://www.sparkfun.com/products/retired/8130)) in ESPHome. It uses [I²C Bus](https://esphome.io/components/i2c.html#i2c) for communication.

*See also: [PCF8574 I/O Expander](https://esphome.io/components/pcf8574.html#pcf8574-i-o-expander)*

*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/binary_sensor/pn532.html#id1)*

pn532_i2c.markdownDescription:
The `pn532` component allows you to use PN532 NFC/RFID controllers ([datasheet](https://cdn-shop.adafruit.com/datasheets/pn532ds.pdf), [Adafruit](https://www.adafruit.com/product/364)) with ESPHome. This component is a global hub that establishes the connection to the PN532 via [I²C](https://esphome.io/components/i2c.html#i2c) and outputs its data. Using the [PN532 binary sensors](https://esphome.io/components/binary_sensor/pn532.html#pn532-tag) you can then create individual binary sensors that track if an NFC/RFID tag is currently detected by the PN532.

*See also: [Over I²C](https://esphome.io/components/binary_sensor/pn532.html#over-i2c)*

id.markdownDescription:

on_tag.markdownDescription:

*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/binary_sensor/pn532.html#configuration-variables)*

pn532_spi.markdownDescription:
The `pn532_spi` component allows you to use PN532 NFC/RFID controllers ([datasheet](https://cdn-shop.adafruit.com/datasheets/pn532ds.pdf), [Adafruit](https://www.adafruit.com/product/364)) with ESPHome. This component is a global hub that establishes the connection to the PN532 via [SPI](https://esphome.io/components/spi.html#spi) and outputs its data. Using the [PN532 binary sensors](https://esphome.io/components/binary_sensor/pn532.html#pn532-tag) you can then create individual binary sensors that track if an NFC/RFID tag is currently detected by the PN532.

*See also: [Over SPI](https://esphome.io/components/binary_sensor/pn532.html#over-spi)*

power_supply.markdownDescription:
The `power_supply` component allows you to have a high power mode for certain outputs. For example, if you’re using an [ATX power supply](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ATX) to power your LED strips, you usually don’t want to have the power supply on all the time while the output is not on. The power supply component can be attached to any [Output Component](https://esphome.io/components/output/index.html#output) and will automatically switch on if any of the outputs are on. Furthermore, it also has a cooldown time that keeps the power supply on for a while after the last output has been disabled.

*See also: [Power Supply Component](https://esphome.io/components/power_supply.html#power-supply-component)*

id.markdownDescription:

prometheus.markdownDescription:
The `prometheus` component enables an HTTP endpoint for the [Web Server Component](https://esphome.io/components/web_server.html) in order to integrate a [Prometheus](https://prometheus.io/) installation.

*See also: [Prometheus Component](https://esphome.io/components/prometheus.html#prometheus-component)*

rc522_i2c.markdownDescription:
The `rc522_i2c` component allows you to use RC522 RFID controllers with ESPHome. This component is a global hub that establishes the connection to the RC522 via [I²C](https://esphome.io/components/i2c.html#i2c) (also avilable over SPI). Using the [RC522 binary sensors](https://esphome.io/components/binary_sensor/rc522.html#rc522-tag) you can then create individual binary sensors that track if an RFID tag is currently detected by the RC522.

*See also: [Over I²C](https://esphome.io/components/binary_sensor/rc522.html#over-i2c)*

rc522_spi.markdownDescription:

This component is a global hub that establishes the connection to the RC522 via [SPI](https://esphome.io/components/spi.html#spi) (also avilable over I²C). Using the [RC522 binary sensors](https://esphome.io/components/binary_sensor/rc522.html#rc522-tag) you can then create individual binary sensors that track if an RFID tag is currently detected by the RC522.

*See also: [Over SPI](https://esphome.io/components/binary_sensor/rc522.html#over-spi)*

remote_receiver.markdownDescription:
The `remote_receiver` component lets you receive and decode any remote signal, these can for example be infrared remotes or 433MHz signals.

*See also: [Remote Receiver](https://esphome.io/components/remote_receiver.html#remote-receiver)*

remote_transmitter.markdownDescription:
The `remote_transmitter` component lets you send digital packets to control devices in your home. For example this includes infrared data or 433MHz RF signals.

*See also: [Remote Transmitter](https://esphome.io/components/remote_transmitter.html#remote-transmitter)*

id.markdownDescription:

on_code_received.markdownDescription:

*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/rf_bridge.html#configuration-variables)*

rf_bridge.markdownDescription:
The `RF Bridge` Component provides the ability to send and receive 433MHz remote codes without hardware hacking the circuit board to bypass the `efm8bb1` MCU. This component implements the communcation protocol that the original `efm8bb1` firmware implements. The device is connected via the [UART bus](https://esphome.io/components/uart.html). The uart bus must be configured at the same speed of the module which is 19200bps.

*See also: [RF Bridge Component](https://esphome.io/components/rf_bridge.html#rf-bridge-component)*

rtttl.markdownDescription:
The `rtttl`, component allows you to easily connect a passive piezo buzzer to your microcontroller and play monophonic songs. It accepts the Ring Tone Text Transfer Language, rtttl format ([Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ring_Tone_Transfer_Language)) which allows to store simple melodies.

*See also: [Rtttl Buzzer](https://esphome.io/components/rtttl.html#rtttl-buzzer)*

servo.markdownDescription:
The `servo` component allows you to use servo motors with ESPHome. Servos are motor controllers that contain all the electronics necessary for driving the motor and provide a simple PWM interface to control the motor.

*See also: [Servo Component](https://esphome.io/components/servo.html#servo-component)*

sim800l.markdownDescription:
The `SIM800L` Component provides the ability to send and receive SMS text messages. The device must be connected via a [UART bus](https://esphome.io/components/uart.html) supporting both receiving and transmitting line. The UART bus must be configured at the same speed of the module which is by default 9600bps. The required connection wires are `+VCC`, `GND`, `RX` and `TX`.

*See also: [Sim800L Component](https://esphome.io/components/sim800l.html#sim800l-component)*

sn74hc595.markdownDescription:
The SN74HC595 component allows you to use SN74HC595 shift registers as I/O expanders ([datasheet](http://www.ti.com/lit/ds/symlink/sn74hc595.pdf), [SparkFun](https://www.sparkfun.com/products/13699)) in ESPHome. It uses 3 wires (optionally 4) for communication.

*See also: [SN74HC595 I/O Expander (shift register)](https://esphome.io/components/sn74hc595.html#sn74hc595-i-o-expander-shift-register)*

sun.markdownDescription:
The `sun` component allows you to track the sun’s position in the sky.

*See also: [Sun](https://esphome.io/components/sun.html#sun)*

sx1509.markdownDescription:
The SX1509 component allows you to expand your I/O capabilities: ([datasheet](https://www.semtech.com/uploads/documents/sx1509_evk_users_guide.pdf), [SparkFun](https://learn.sparkfun.com/tutorials/sx1509-io-expander-breakout-hookup-guide/all)) in ESPHome. It uses [I²C Bus](https://esphome.io/components/i2c.html#i2c) for communication.

*See also: [SX1509 16 channel I/O Expander with LED driver and keypad engine](https://esphome.io/components/sx1509.html#sx1509-16-channel-i-o-expander-with-led-driver-and-keypad-engine)*

tm1651.markdownDescription:
The `tm1651` display platform allows you to use battery display units based on TM1651 chip, like [this one](https://aliexpress.com/item/32811491559.html) with ESPHome. Currently integration supports level and brightness setting. All updates can be made via lambda expressions.

*See also: [TM1651 Battery Display](https://esphome.io/components/tm1651.html#tm1651-battery-display)*

time_id.markdownDescription:
[ID](https://esphome.io/guides/configuration-types.html#config-id): Some Tuya devices support obtaining local time from ESPHome. Specify the ID of the [Time Component](https://esphome.io/components/time.html#time) which will be used.



*See also: [Configuration variables:](https://esphome.io/components/tuya.html#configuration-variables)*
